subject: Productivity
title: Curiosity as a Drive
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on Curiosity as a Drive.

hook.text: Monkeys will work to open a window and look outside even with no food reward. Curiosity itself is motivating.

buildup.text: George Loewenstein's information gap theory says curiosity arises when we sense a gap in our knowledge.

discovery.text: That gap creates discomfort. Closing it feels rewarding. Curiosity is a built-in drive to learn.

twist.text: Clickbait exploits this. Headlines create information gaps on purpose. Your brain can't resist closing them.

climax.text: Harnessing curiosity at work means framing tasks as puzzles to solve, not duties to complete.

punchline.text: Curiosity isn't idle. It's one of your strongest drives.

quiz.question: What creates the feeling of curiosity according to Loewenstein?
options: Sensing a gap in your knowledge
